titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Film collection FA466
titlestmt.author: Laura Montgomery

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-08-11 02:27:41 -0400.

did.physdesc: Approximately 1500 films.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: When requesting to view films -- please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1902).
If the item does not have a designated AV number, please refer to the Title and the Film Number (which consists of a combination of Roman numerals and alphanumerics - example: III 14.1-6).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The films are arranged into 23 series based primarily on original provenance. When provenance is unknown, material is designated according to the subject matter and/or the primary individual/institution associated with the given subject or activity.

Series 1: AIA/IBEC. Series 2: Asia Society. Series 3: John C. Bugher. Series 4: Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs (CIAA). Series 5: Harold P. Fabian. Series 6: Ford Foundation. Series 7: Frederick W. Knipe. Series 8: Rockefeller family, General. Series 9: John D. Rockefeller. Series 10: John D. Rockefeller Jr. Series 11: Abby Rockefeller Mauze ("Babs") Series 12: John D. Rockefeller 3rd. Series 13: Nelson A. Rockefeller, Personal. Series 14: Nelson A. Rockefeller, Political Career. Series 15: Laurance S. Rockefeller. Series 16: Winthrop Rockefeller. Series 17: David Rockefeller. Series 18: Rockefeller Foundation. Series 19: Rockefeller University. Series 20: Paul Ehrlich. Series 21: Paul A. Weiss Laboratory. Series 22: William H. Whyte. Series 23: General or Miscellaneous films.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: All inquires to view films require advanced notice of at least 24 hours, and may necessitate notice of up to one week. Individual items, including those that are not available in modern formats, may be restricted from scholarly access at the discretion of RAC.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: The majority of Films have been physically separated from an archival collection.
In most cases, the specific details of the provenance are simply unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Film collection is an artificial collection created by the RAC in order to efficiently and effectively manage and present the moving images held among our archival holdings.
This material includes films and moving images in virtually every format available since the early 20th century including but not necessarily limited to: 16mm, 35mm, beta, Super 8, VHS and DVD.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Since the contents of the Film collection have inherently been separated from other archival holdings, the description of any individual item, or set of items, may also currently appear, in some form, in the finding aid for the originating collection.
Future processing, description, and presentation of Films will seek to address this issue as much as feasible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The RAC has a collection of films in English and Spanish made for the use of IBEC, including films on tropical diets, agricultural practices and improvements, housing in Puerto Rico, and food production.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The American International Association for Economic and Social Development was established by Nelson Rockefeller in 1946 as an outgrowth of his work as Coordinator for Inter-American Affairs. With a similar mission, the International Basic Economy Corporation was established in 1947 to enhance the economic and social growth of developing countries, particularly in Latin America.

did.physdesc: The entire Bugher Collection was digitized in 2011 and is available for viewing on DVD.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dr. Bugher was a staff member of the Rockefeller Foundation and worked with the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The RAC has a number of films from the 1920s and 1930s that show Bugher's work on yellow fever in Africa, the Balkans, Greece, and South America. Scenes of villages and traditional practices, malaria treatments, efforts to combat mosquitoes, and some later footage relating to the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission (ca. 1950-1960).

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note

did.unittitle: Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs (CIAA)
did.physdesc: All of the CIAA films are available on DVD, except where noted.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Under Nelson Rockefeller, the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs was created to support various health and social wellness initiatives, as well as to maintain cultural and commercial relations between North and South America. From 1940 to 1946, the CIAA used films and posters to advertise their projects in Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Haiti, Mexico, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1942, the CIAA contracted Walt Disney Studios to produce 18 films, all of which are available at the RAC. An additional set of films produced by the Julien Bryan Studio created for a primary and secondary level school audience were not commissioned individually by the CIAA, but are included here because of their related content. Many of these films are in Spanish, and some are animated features, or a combination of animation and live-action.

There is a substantial amount of documentation about these films in the Nelson Rockefeller papers. These reels, including the material produced by Walt Disney Productions, are thought to be Nelson Rockefeller’s personal copies.

scopecontent.p: The films included in the collection are the products of various grants and internal initiatives, dating from the early 1950s.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation is a nonprofit grant-making organization with an extensive history of international leadership in economic development, human rights and microfinance, as well as major U.S. causes, including the environment, civil rights, legal aid, and women's rights, and such domestic challenges as urban development and reproductive health.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Overcrowded prisons and outdated systems in Georgia required the state to explore nontraditional sentencing structures - their successes are documented in this short film. At the threat of federal involvement, the state designed new alternatives to prison time. The film shows several tiers of options for nonviolent criminals, and discusses the challenges and accomplishments of the programs. Funded by the Ford Foundation and the JFK School of Government at Harvard. Produced by David Jordan, copyright 1988 by GDC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Showcase of education and training opportunities for young people in Nigeria. A four-year study by the American Institute for Research and the US Agency for International Development produced an aptitude test, which was incorporated into school and professional systems throughout Nigeria. Details of the test and its outcomes are presented. This film is presented by the Ford Foundation in cooperation with the public authorities of Nigeria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This film is based on the report and reccommendations of the Ford Foundation project on socil welfare and the American Future. The documentary offeres new ways to think about child care, welfare, the working poor, displaced workers, healthcare, the ederly, addiction issues and homelessness. It was produced for the Ford Foundation by Dick Young Productions, Ltd. New York City. Copyright 1990, Dick Young.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film report by the Fund for Adult Education, of the Ford Foundation, about an experiment in designing and supporting community leaders. 275 local leaders from all over the United States were invited for a two-week retreat of workshops and discussions on resolving community issues, communication tools, local resources, and other topics. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An introduction to the Continental Classroom film series and its early research in educational TV programming and satellite education. An initial summary of pilot programs precedes Episode 147 of the series,"Nuclear Rhythms", with Dr. Felix Bloch (director of the Manhattan Project). The series was funded by the Ford Foundation, Standard Oil Company of California, the Fund for the Advancement of Education, and many others. Produced by NBC and the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An episode of Edward R. Murrow's"See It Now" broadcast featuring a discussion with Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced Study. Murrow and Oppenheimer discuss the history of the Institute, its current fellows and projects, and its goals for the future in technology and science. Filmed 1955 January 4, this film is an extended version of the original aired broadcast (re-released for college and university use).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film about the Exploratorium Science Museum in San Francisco, CA. Interactive exhibits about light, sound, energy, and other natural phenomena are shown, using optical illusions, kinetic artworks, displays of frequency and pitch, and other methods. The end of the film shows the museum founder, Dr. Frank Oppenheimer, discussing the impact of the exhibits with the staff. This film was shot by Jon Boorstin and funded by the National Education Association and the National Science Foundation. Copyright 1975, Jon Boorstin and the Exploratorium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A 2-part documentary about issues of housing, taxes, and inequality in the NY region, including NYC and parts of NJ and CT. This episode is the first in a series of "televised town meetings" designed to face issues within the area and encourage civic dialogue. The series, "Choices for 76", was timed to address challenges and solutions in preparation for the Bicentennial of the USA. The series was presented by the Regional Plan Association in the spring of 1973, which published an accompany text entitled "How to Save Urban America", as well as other newspaper and print articles. Produced by David Sawyer and Albert Waller, in collaboration with the US Department of Housing and Urban Development. Funded by a variety of institutions, including the Ford Foundation, Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the Taconic Foundation and Rockefeller Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An introductory history of the Ford Foundation, its trustees and programs during the 1950s given by Henry Ford II and H. Rowan Gaither. Henry Ford II introduces the board of trustees- Frank W. Abrams, James F. Brownlee, John Cowles, Donald K. David, Mark F. Ethridge, Laurence M. Gould, John J. McCloy, Charles Wilson, Charles E. Wyzanski, Jr., H. Rowan Gaither, Jr. and Benson Ford. Clips of "Goan Sathis", "Kennan on Communism" and "Community Leadership Institute" are used as examples of the types of work being done at the Ford Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film about the Housing Authority struggle in St. Louis in 1969 over tenement housing focused on the Pruitt-Igoe urban housing project. It examines the resident-management program in public housing projects in St. Louis. The film shows how the program has solved many of the problems of the residents and relieved the atmosphere of confrontation which plagued public housing in St. Louis before the introduction of the program. Copyright Ford Foundation, 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A documentary for the Human Ecology Fund and directed by Raymond Prince, MD. Section of Transcultural Psychiatric Studies, McGill University. The film documents psychiatric disorders and Yerubic medicine in Yeruba, Nigeria. The documentary includes footage of diagnosis, treatment, care of patients, spiritual healing ceremonies, male and female cult practices, and comparisons of traditional Yerubic religion, Islam and Christianity?s relationship to psychiatric illness. Contains footage of animal sacrifice and female nudity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller family films represent a mix of private family footage, and published recordings from a multitude of sources. In the 1970s and 1980s, a reorganization effort duplicated and merged many of the original Rockefeller family films, so there is frequent overlap and repetition of some scenes, and many films contain a mix of private and public footage.
See the Archival Services staff for more information about these films or guidance on finding a scene.
The Rockefeller family (General) films contains moving images of multiple family members.

Thereafter, are individual series focused on materials pertaining to, or otherwise related to, the activities of each prominent member of the Rockefeller family "Brothers Generation". Family members may be referred to by their full name, nickname, or abbreviation (such as NAR).

scopecontent.p: Episode from the newsreel series March of Time, a news compilation based on and sponsored by Time Magazine. HBO maintains copyright of this series. Includes NYC: scenes at Rockefeller Center: the family office, Room 5600; JDR JR working in office; construction; murals and artwork; Radio City and the Rockettes; the Rainbow Room; Rockefeller University; University of Chicago; Colonial Williamsburg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Film about the projects and ideas generated around the Bicentennial. Introduced by President Ford, the film features interviews with prominent figures and examines civic projects all looking to examine the history of the US so far, and to make constructive plans for the future. Interviews with JDR 3rd, Ladybird Johnson, Dr. Jonas Salk, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A study of the performing arts in America, supported by JDR 3rd. The study stresses that the arts should have the same public funding and accessibility as museums or libraries, and the importance of bringing professional standards and quality to community and school-level programs. Barbara Walters and Hugh Downs are the interviewers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The second half of a film about the ERLAAS project in Sardinia (The first half is "The Sardinian Project"). Describes the land and people of Sardinia before the malaria eradication program - difficulties of life in villages, land defoliated, rampant disease, and so on. Introduces the ERLAAS staff, under the direction of Dr. John Loyan, and their efforts to combat the disease using DDT spray over 10,000 square miles. Produced by British Pathe Production for the Economic Cooperation Administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection has received basic processing to establish initial physical and intellectual control, but the content remains generally unidentified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The RAC has a collection of some 500 films with minimal descriptive or technical information; most are views of chemical samples through a microscope and related laboratory processes, although there is some footage of lectures and presentations by Dr. Weiss. Original can notations include such titles as Salam Nerve Fiber, Margins of Liver and Kidney Cells, and Cleveland Lecture.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Weiss was a biologist and professor who worked at the Rockefeller University for over 15 years.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged as received, in original order.

did.unittitle: Dr. Paul A. Weiss Laboratory Films
did.physdesc: 500 films. Silent, Black & white, varying lengths. Only available on original 16mm film.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: All inquires to view films require advanced notice of at least 24 hours, and may necessitate notice of up to one week. Individual items, including those not available in modern formats, may be restricted from scholarly access at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: As the mentor for initiatives such as the Project for Public Spaces and the Street Life Project in the 1960’s and 1970’s, William H. Whyte based his theories about urban planning and social movement on hours of footage and time-lapse photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection of edited and raw films held at the RAC come from Whyte’s work with the American Conservation Association and his role as an advisor to Laurance Rockefeller. A majority of the Whyte films are unedited trims and original clips, compiled into final films at a later date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Film from the Neurophysiology Laboratories and the Division of Psychiatry at the Otho S.A. Sprague Memorial Institute and the University of Chicago. Summary of experimental work by Jules H. Masserman, M.D., University of Chicago, and Adam Wikler, M.D., U.S. Public Health Service. Contains some graphic footage of experiments on cats in a laboratory setting.
